data.name: Cat Nips
data.detailed_description:
In this reverse horror game you inflict the terror! You've broken out of your containment cell. Now is the perfect time to unleash chaos. It'll take skill to escape alive. There are potential dangers around every corner as you explore what remains of an office. There are signs that someone went here before, a bloody someone.

Features:

  • Eat your enemies - Office workers may not all be part of this scheme, but is mercy more important than a snack ? Use your sharp teeth to eat almost anything you run into !


  • Inflitration & Stealth - Cut your way through an office filled with guards, cameras and other dangers ! Use stealth to avoid detection of the nearby guards or eat them. Your life depends on it...


  • Discover the truth - Will you uncover the mysteries of your presence in this place ? Find out what happened and who is responsible for capturing you and giving you this fairly well-developed dentition.

  • Avoid the bigger fish - The unspeakable experiments performed on you made you strong, but you weren't the only test subject. In fact the other may be closer than you think, do not get caught by them or else you will pay the price...

Why would you eat a desk ?

data.short_description: Cat Nips is a game about a cat eating people to escape an office. This cat will need to sneak past guards, cameras and other dangers in order to escape.

pc_requirements.minimum:
Minimum:
  • OS: Windows 7+
  • Processor: 2.0 GHz+ 32-bit
  • Memory: 1 GB RAM
  • Graphics: ATI Radeon X1300, NVIDIA GeForce 6600 GT
  • Storage: 100 MB available space
  • Sound Card: Any
  • Additional Notes: The game is not resource heavy but these still might change in the future

linux_requirements.minimum:
Minimum:
  • OS: Debian 11
  • Processor: 2.0 GHz+ 32 bit
  • Memory: 1 GB RAM
  • Graphics: ATI Radeon X1300, NVIDIA GeForce 6600 GT
  • Storage: 100 MB available space
  • Sound Card: Any
  • Additional Notes: Currently only tested on Debian but it should work on any distro. The game is not resource heavy but these still might change in the future.
